CVD_SDOH.TEXT:
S: Subjective Chief Complaint: “I’ve been feeling more tingling in my feet and my blood sugars have been higher than usual.” History of Present Illness: Mr. John Doe is a 58-year-old male with a known history of Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus (T2DM), Hypertension, and Hyperlipidemia who presents for routine follow-up. Over the past month, he has noticed increased numbness and tingling in both feet, worse at night. The symptoms are bilateral, non-radiating, and described as “pins and needles.” He denies any new trauma, redness, or ulcers. He has also observed fasting blood glucose levels between 160-190 mg/dL and post-prandial readings occasionally exceeding 220 mg/dL, which is a change from his prior average of 130–150 mg/dL fasting. He has not changed his medication or diet significantly. He admits to some recent increased stress and skipped exercise due to workload. He denies vision changes, shortness of breath, chest pain, orthopnea, paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea, palpitations, dizziness, or syncope. No abdominal pain, diarrhea, or constipation. No hematuria or dysuria. No recent infections or fevers. Medications: Metformin 1000 mg BID
Lisinopril 20 mg daily
Atorvastatin 40 mg nightly
Aspirin 81 mg daily
Allergies: No known drug allergies (NKDA) Past Medical History: Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus, diagnosed 2014
Hypertension
Hyperlipidemia
Obesity (BMI 31.2)
Past Surgical History: Appendectomy, 1990
No recent surgeries
Family History: Father: T2DM, deceased from MI at age 68
Mother: Hypertension, alive, age 82
No family history of cancer
Social History: Non-smoker
Drinks alcohol occasionally (1–2 beers/week)
Denies illicit drug use
Works full time as an accountant
Lives with wife, independent in ADLs
Review of Systems: General: No weight change, no fever, no chills
Neurological: Reports tingling in both feet; no weakness, no falls
Cardiovascular: Denies chest pain, palpitations
Pulmonary: No shortness of breath or cough
GI: No abdominal pain, nausea, or vomiting
GU: No dysuria or hematuria
Skin: No rash or wounds noted
Musculoskeletal: No joint pain or swelling
O: Objective Vital Signs: BP: 138/82 mmHg
HR: 78 bpm
RR: 16/min
Temp: 98.6 °F
SpO₂: 98% on room air
Weight: 198 lbs
Height: 5’9”
BMI: 31.2 (Obese)
Physical Exam: General: Alert and oriented, NAD
HEENT: PERRLA, EOMI, no oral lesions
Neck: No lymphadenopathy, thyroid non-enlarged
Cardiac: RRR, no murmurs, rubs, or gallops
Lungs: Clear to auscultation bilaterally
Abdomen: Soft, nontender, no organomegaly
Extremities: No edema, pulses 2+ bilaterally
Neuro:
CN II-XII grossly intact
Decreased pinprick sensation in bilateral feet up to ankles
Reflexes diminished at Achilles, normal at patella
No tremor or muscle atrophy
Skin: Intact, no ulcers, no erythema
Labs: (Most recent labs from 1 week ago) HbA1c: 8.3% ↑ (previous: 7.1% six months ago)
Fasting glucose: 174 mg/dL
LDL: 96 mg/dL
HDL: 42 mg/dL
Triglycerides: 180 mg/dL
Creatinine: 1.0 mg/dL
eGFR: >60
Urine microalbumin: 32 mg/g
A: Assessment Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus – Poorly controlled
HbA1c increased from 7.1% to 8.3% in 6 months
Home glucose readings elevated
Likely contributing factors: decreased physical activity, stress, possible early neuropathy
No evidence of nephropathy or retinopathy at this visit
Peripheral Neuropathy – Likely diabetic origin
Progressive bilateral tingling and decreased sensation in feet
No evidence of ulcers or active infection
Consistent with length-dependent sensory neuropathy
Hypertension – Controlled
BP today 138/82 mmHg
No reported symptoms, continues Lisinopril
Hyperlipidemia – Borderline LDL, lifestyle reinforcement needed
LDL improved with statin, but TG slightly elevated
Reinforce dietary adherence and follow-up labs in 6 months
Obesity – Stable, but no weight loss
BMI remains >30
Encourage increased physical activity and dietary adherence
P: Plan For Diabetes: Add GLP-1 receptor agonist (e.g., semaglutide) starting at 0.25 mg weekly to help with glycemic control and weight management
Continue Metformin 1000 mg BID
Reinforce dietary counseling: refer to dietitian for 1:1 session
Encourage return to regular physical activity (e.g., 30 mins walk daily, 5x/week)
Recheck HbA1c in 3 months
Continue home glucose monitoring; patient instructed to log values
For Neuropathy: Start Gabapentin 100 mg TID, titrate as needed
Monitor for side effects: dizziness, somnolence
Foot care education provided: inspect daily, avoid walking barefoot, report any ulcers or cuts
Schedule diabetic foot exam every 6 months
For Hypertension and Hyperlipidemia: Continue current regimen (Lisinopril, Atorvastatin)
No changes today
For Obesity and Lifestyle: Reinforce importance of exercise and portion control
Provided resources for local diabetes education classes
Discussed potential role of weight loss in improving glycemic control and neuropathy symptoms
Follow-up: 3-month follow-up for repeat labs, foot exam, and diabetes reassessment
Call sooner if neuropathy symptoms worsen or new signs of infection develop
Patient Understanding & Agreement: The patient verbalized understanding of his new medication and lifestyle plan. He is motivated to improve his control and agrees to follow up as scheduled.

Physical_Activity.text: regular physical activity (e.g., 30 mins walk daily, 5x/week)

Treatment_Adherence.text: Continue home glucose monitoring; patient instructed to log values

Employment.text: Works full time as an accountant
